translation1: "Since its introduction in 2001, the Valvetronix series from VOX has continuously evolved, leading to the combination of advanced modeling technology with the \"Valve Reactor\" circuitry, which perfectly imitates the behavior of a tube amplifier. With the VT20X/VT40X/VT100X amplifiers, we are presenting a brand new modeling engine that is absolutely state-of-the-art in terms of sound. Thanks to the VET (Virtual Element Technology) technology, which is based on the analysis of components and amplifier circuits, the VTX amplifiers wait with an authenticity that is absolutely impressive.Of course, these amps also feature the multi-stage Valvetronix tube preamplifier. This design partly relies on genuine analog circuits because these can better capture the sound variations and nuances of a tube amplifier than any simulation. In addition to this sophisticated circuitry, VTX amplifiers offer a closed housing and a bass reflex system, from which the natural resonances just flow.With the \"Tone Room\" software from VOX, you can even correct and bend historical facts on the virtual level, so that the amp and effects sound exactly as you have always imagined them. The perfect combination of tube sound with modeling technology is primarily due to the 2001 introduced VOX Valve Reactor technology. Of course, it has been refined several times since then to meet new sound requirements, which led to a performance boost of the VOX Valvetronix series in 2010 - with more dynamics as well as numerous and significantly improved amplifier models.From the handy VT20+ to the VT120+ with two speakers, the new VT+ Valvetronix series was also designed in such a way that all guitarists in search of maximum sound diversity will hit the jackpot. All guitarists dream of the compression and dynamics of a tube amplifier: they expect a fat sound, nuanced reproduction of playing dynamics and string attack, as well as prompt response. During an in-depth analysis, VOX engineers discovered that the final stage determines the tube character of an amplifier and developed based on this finding the VOX Valve Reactor technology.The valve reactor circuit of each VT+ amplifier, equipped with a 12AX7 tube, perfectly reproduces the behavior, subtle nuances, and sound character of a tube amplifier."
gpt_response: { "Accuracy": { "Mistakes": [ {"type": "Omission", "details": "Omitted 'groundbreaking' in the description about modeling technology in the Valvetronix series"}, {"type": "Omission", "details": "Omitted 'multi-leveled' in the description of the Valvetronix tube amplifiers in the text to evaluate."}, {"type": "Wrong Translation", "details": "The term 'wait with an authenticity' in the evaluation text should be 'puts forth an authenticity' as in the reference text."}, {"type": "Omission", "details": "The detail about the amplifier 'dealing with real analogue circuits' is missing in the text to be evaluated."}, {"type": "Omission", "details": "The phrase 'you can even correct and bend historical facts on a virtual plane' in the reference text is changed to 'you can even correct and bend historical facts on the virtual level' in the evaluated text, but the term 'plane' is more suitable and specific in this context."}, {"type": "Wrong Translation", "details": "The terms 'pressure' and 'chord strokes' related to the guitarists' expectations from a tube amp in the reference text are changed to 'compression' and 'string attack' in the translation. While the meanings are similar, they're not an exact match and could be misleading."}] } }
reference: Since its introduction in 2001, the Valvetronix series from VOX has continuously been improved, which has lead to, among other things, the combination of groundbreaking modeling technology with the “Valve Reactor” circuit with which the behavior of a tube amplifies is perfectly reproduced. With the VT20X/VT40X/VT100X amps, we present a brand-new modeling engine, which is the absolute state-of-the-art in the field of sound. Thanks to VET technology (Virtual Element Technology), which utilizes an analysis of the components and amp circuits, the VTX amplifier puts forth an authenticity, which is absolutely impressive. These amps also include the multi-leveled Valvetronix tube amplifiers, of course. This deals with real analogue circuits, because these simply are better than any simulation at obtaining the sound variations and nuances of a tube amplifier. In addition to this sophisticated circuitry, the VTX amplifier offers a closed casing and bass reflex system, from which natural resonances just burst out. With VOX’s “Tone Room” software, you can even correct and bend historical facts on a virtual plane until the amp and the effects sound just like you have always imagined them. The perfect combination of tube sound with modeling technology is above all thanks to the VOX valve reactor technology introduced in 2001. Naturally, it has been refined ever since then in order to handle new sound requirements, which in 2010 lead to a renewed power boost to the VOX Valvetronix series with more dynamics as well as numerous, decisively improved amplifier models. From the handy VT20+ to the VT120+ with two speakers, the new VT+ Valvetronix series has additionally been designed in such a way that all guitarists looking for maximum sound variety will find what they need here. All guitarists dream of the pressure and the dynamics of a tube amp: They want a fat sound, a nuanced playback of playing dynamics and chord strokes, as well as a prompt response. During an in-depth analysis the VOX engineers discovered that the output stage above all else determines the tube character of an amplifier and they developed the VOX Valve reactor technology on the basis of this discovery. The Valve reactor circuit of any VT+ amplifier equipped with a 12AX7 tube produces the character, the subtle nuances and the sound shape of a tube amplifier perfectly.

translation1: "Basketball Bundesliga: Derby Disaster for MHP Riesen Ludwigsburg against Merlins Crailsheim At least one youngster, Johannes Patrick, was left. Again nothing: For the second time within less than three months, the Riesen lost in Crailsheim - and how!Before the game, Ludwigsburg's coach John Patrick looked back on the cup defeat in early October at the Hakro Merlins Crailsheim and said: \"We still have some anger in our stomach.\" However, this anger did not subside after the game, but rather intensified due to the 61:72 (28:38) loss in the Basketball Bundesliga. Whereas the result alone was disappointing, it was the way the team performed that was even more disappointing.Substitute a statistic for the entire dilemma: The triple quote amounted to just 13 percent, 4 goals (all from young Johannes Patrick) in 31 attempts - any more questions? John Patrick's answer was: \"We weren't concentrated enough after our victory at Tenerife and didn't implement what we had trained.\" Specifically, moving the ball.Sebastian Gleim reacted quite differently to his counterpart: \"What a great game to win for the second time against Ludwigsburg,\" said the happy coach. \"It felt like playing in front of 10,000 people.\" However, there were only 750 spectators allowed at the Hohenlohe Arena on Saturday, but they made up for it.Not only because of BBL top scorer T.J. Shorts, who marked 22 points and led his team. \"The best playmaker I have ever trained,\" praised Gleim. While in Patrick's team, the key performers like Jordan Hulls (0 points) and Jonah Radebaugh (7) failed throughout the line.Only in the last quarter (22:15) did the giants prevent a total disaster and came within eight points after being behind 39:59. Besides Johannes Patrick, Justin Simon also scored 12 points. Fortunately, there was not much time for bickering.Already on Wednesday (7 PM), the giants will receive the Skyliners Frankfurt, followed by a game in Ludwigsburg with a maximum of 750 spectators."

Shorts as 'The best playmaker I have ever trained,' where the reference text refers to him as 'The best player, who I have ever trained.'.", "Omission: The evaluated text does not include 'it increased once again after the 61-72 (28-38)' from the reference text." ]} }
reference: National basket ball league: Derby-Debakel, MHP Ludwigsburg Giants at Merlins Crailsheim At least the youngster Johannes Patrick was reliable. Nothing, again: For the second time within less than three months the Giants lost in Crailsheim - and how! John Patrick, the trainer for Ludwigsburg, said before the game in reference to the previous finals loss in the beginning of October to HAKRO Crailsheim Merlins that: “We are still angry about it”. But this was note put to rest after the game, but rather it increased once again after the 61-72 (28-38) defeat in the basketball league. It wasn’t just the score that was disappointing, but also the way they showed up. A statistic was given for this which expresses the whole dilemma: The triple quota was only 13 percent, 4 hits (all from the young Johannes Patrick) and a whopping 31 attempts - any questions? The answer was given by John Patrick: “We were simply not concentrated enough after the victory at Teneriffa and we didn’t put into practice what we had trained.” They just didn’t move the ball. His counterpart Sebastian Gleim reacted much differently: “It was an awesome game winning for the second time against Ludwigsburg,” the happy coach said. “It felt like it was in front of 10,000 people.” 750 people were let into the Hohenlohe Arena on Saturday, and they got what they paid for. Not least of all because of the BBL top shooter T.J. Shorts, who landed 22 pointes and steered the game for his team. “The best player, who I have ever trained,“ said Gleim in praise. While at the same time on Patricks Team even the top performers like Jordan Hulls (0 points) and Jonah Radebaugh (7) failed when they got to the line. Only in the last quarter (22:15) did the giants prevent a total debacle and came within eight points, after which they were knocked back down to 39:59. Not just Johannes Patrick but Justin Simon also scored twelve points. There was luckily not a lot of time to fight. On Wednesday (7 PM) the giants will already host Skyliners Frankfurt in front of a maximum of 750 spectators in Ludwigsburg.

Kennedy Street.

translation1: "I am bored with Sky Sport F1 Hello dear F1 fans, throughout the season, the quality on the German Sky has decreased so much that I need to vent a bit with this post. First of all, the transmission was interrupted during the F2 race to start the F1 coverage on time.Although the delayed start and the accident at the beginning put the schedule far behind schedule, it would still have been possible to show the last (planned) ten minutes as well as the championship decision (!) if necessary. However, it seems that for legal reasons, F1 has priority and everything else has to be restricted, so Sky DE probably had no choice. Nevertheless, it's still stupid, especially since Sky UK broadcast the race to the end.Nonetheless, a small compliment: commentator Olivier Zwartjes has accompanied the difficult situation around the serious accident well. Then there was again a rule misunderstanding among the commentators Sascha Roos and Ralf Schumacher, as both did not know that you can change tires under a red flag in F1. Although this situation had already occurred in Imola, Baku, and Silverstone this year, both only came to the conclusion that Verstappen could change tires when there were relevant radio messages about this topic to Hamilton.At Sky UK and RTL, both commentators immediately knew that there was a possibility for Verstappen. I believe that one should simply know such elementary rules if they comment on the F1 on a pay-TV channel. It is also not the first riddle that is now possible or prescribed according to the rules. Both have constant uncertainties in the topic of rules.Generally, Roos' artificial commenting style doesn't appeal to me, but I have to admit that it's a matter of taste. However, I genuinely find Heiko Water from RTL better. There are constant nonsensical things that both come across as unprofessional, such as ordering coffee from the equally clueless reporter Peter Hardenacke or \"UuuuuHD\" from Ralf Schumacher.The latest commentator is causing a lot of commotion in the comments, which seems not to take him seriously. Not least, advertising takes over on Sky, while in the final stretch, Sky is the only channel that goes into advertising, as you can hear the German commentary without commentary after the race on F1TV. Neither ServusTV nor ORF do this.Although these two channels show less advertising than Sky, and as free TV channels, I must say that Glock and Baumgartner deserve praise for their work. However, this does not allow me to overlook the disadvantages. The rest of the Sky Sports F1 program is also very sparse and full of repeats.Overall, Sky is really the worst German-speaking broadcaster to transmit the F1. Ironically, RTL does a better job with the four races they are still allowed to broadcast, excluding advertising. So, the fantastic F1 season makes significantly less fun than it would with a reasonable broadcaster.I would be interested in your opinion."
gpt_response: { "Accuracy": { "Mistakes": [ "Wrong Translation: The first sentence translation changed 'annoyed' in the reference text to 'bored' in the text to evaluate. The two words have different meanings.", "Omission: The evaluator text skipped about the difference between rules understanding of the Sky UK and RTL at Sky Germany.", "Addition: There's an addition of 'Ironically' in the very last part of the evaluator text mentioning about RTL which is not present in the reference text", "Wrong Translation: The reference text mentioned about the 'falling accident' while the evaluator text changed it to 'serious accident' " ]} }
reference: I am annoyed with Sky Sport F1 Hello F1 fans, the quality of German Sky decreased over the course of the season, such that I want to clear it up some with this post. First things first, today the transmission broke off in the middle of the F2 race in order to punctually begin the pre-show reporting of the F1. It was because of the delayed start and the falling accident that the schedule was so far behind what was planned, but you still could have let the last (planned) 10 minutes show as well as the tournament decision (!). Apparently because of legal reasons, F1 has priority and because of that everything else needs to be restricted such that Sky Germany didn’t really have a choice here. It is still dumb, because Sky UK transmitted the race up until the very end. In spite of that, some small praise: the announcer Olivier Zwartyes was a good accompaniment to the difficult situation and the unfortunate accident. In the F1 there was even knowledge gaps of the rules in the commentary by Sascha Roos and Ralf Schumacher, both of them didn’t know that during a red flag the tires are allowed to be changed. Although this situation already came up this year in Imola, Baku and Silverstone, they both first came to the conclusion that Verstappen was allowed to switch his tires following corresponding radio messages on the topic to Hamilton. The announcers at Sky UK and RTL knew immediately that this was a possibility for Verstappen. I am of the opinion that knowledge of such elementary rules should be assumed if you are going to provide F1 commentary on a paid-for TV broadcaster. It's also not the first guessing game as to what is possible or required by the rules, both of them have constant uncertainties regarding rules. In general I don’t really like the artificial style of the commentary from Roos, but I’ll admit that is a manner of taste. But even Heiko Wasser from RTL does it better in my honest opinion. Additionally, there are just absurdities, which make the two of them seem unprofessional, like the ordering of coffee with the (just as clueless) reporter Peter Hardenacke or the “Ahhhh HD” from Ralf Schumacher. This last part really brings a lot of agitation into the commentary which he doesn’t take seriously. Not least of all, the advertising is just so prevalent on Sky, in the cool-down lap Sky is the only broadcaster that still goes to commercials, like you can hear this on F1TV, because only the German audio track comes out without commentary right after the race. Neither ServusTV nor ORF do this. Both of these broadcasters also do less commercials than Sky during training, and they are free TV broadcasters. You even have to congratulate Glock and Baumgartner for their work, but that alone doesn’t cause me to overlook the disadvantages. The normal program from Sky Sport F1 is also very sparse and full of repetitions. All in all, Sky is really the worst German-speaking broadcaster that transmits the F1. In all honesty, RTL does a better job of transmitting the four races which they are allowed to transmit, including even the advertisements. At any rate, it really makes the grand F1 season considerably less fun as would be the case with a reasonable broadcaster. I would be really interested in your opinion.
